name: weaned calves production on native pasture, Pantanal | cattle for slaughtering, live weight | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/20471/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of live weight of weaned calves for beef cattle, in Brazil, mostly on native pasture (2% of planted pasture), at farm, in Brazilian Pantanal biome, for fattening by other systems. Discarded cattle (bulls and culled cows) are considered by product. Culled cows are replaced by some of the weaned heifers, all other weaned heifers are sold for fattening by other systems, and are considered by product. Fences are the only infrastructure included. The production of young bulls for reproduction is not included, but their emissions in the farm and their live weight as product are considered. Direct field emissions are included, with important regionalizations added. Farm manure as an organic fertiliser is only accounted for in terms of direct field emissions. 

This activity starts at the replacing of culled cows by weaned heifers.

This activity ends with the provision of weaned calves at farm gate, ready to be sent to slaughterhouses as live weight.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/014:Animal production/0141:Raising of cattle and buffaloes

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Time period of the most of the data collected for this dataset.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: 'At more than 138 000 km2, the Brazilian Pantanal is known as the largest freshwater wetland in the world. The Pantanal is home to at least 650 species of birds, 260 species of fish, 80 mammal species, 50 species of reptiles (Wade et al., 1993), and more than 2000 identified floral species (Pott, 1998). Among its most renowned fauna are the jaguar, jaburu stork, blue hyacinth macaw, capybara, anaconda, giant anteater, coati and piranha. The Pantanal's principal economic activities include fishing, mining, tourism, and cattle ranching. Extensive cattle ranching has been the dominant economic activity and land use in the region for the past two centuries. About 95% of Pantanal lands are privately owned. About 80% (118 000 km2) of the lands are found on cattle ranches (Silva et al., 2000). The estimated present value of the existing herd of 3 million is about US$1 billion (Seidl et al., 1999).' Ecological Economics Volume 36, Issue 3, March 2001, Pages 413-425 Cattle ranching and deforestation in the Brazilian Pantanal;Andrew F Seidl Joao dos Santos Vila de Silva Andre Steffens Moraes.; https://doi.org/10.1016/S0921-8009(00)00238-X
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Mineral salt is served as supplement feed for all cattle in troughs on the field. Besides pasture and mineral salt, no suplement is served to cattle. The dataset does not include pharmaceuticals, although typical production systems use them. Use of hormones for cattle raising is forbidden in Brazil.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Carbon content, water and gross calorific value are based on ecoinvent database.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Inventory data for cattle systems obtained from Embrapa’s PECUS Project, literature and expert knowledge. Emissions from the agricultural process estimated according to Nemecek and Schnetzer (2011) and Canals (2003) and other references mentioned.

flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: As phosphorus leaching must be disregarded due to its low mobility in Brazilian soils (Novais & Smyth, 1999), only P emission by water erosion through surface water was considered, as in '2.3.3 Phorsphorous Emissions Through Water Erosion to Surface Water' Nemecek and Schnetzer (2011). Soil eroded is 200 kg/ha.yr.

flow.name: Phosphorus
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to water/surface water

exchanges.description: Emissions of CO2 to air from limestone and urea application based on IPCC (2006).

flow.name: Carbon dioxide, fossil
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: Drinking water for animals, from well, lakes, rivers or rain. Consumption of 0.14 liters per day per kg of cattle live weight was multiplied per kg of average live weight for each heard category. Consumption per kg of live weight was estimated from PALHARES, 2013 considering that each range of weight and consumption begins at the end of the previous range, and that the first range presented on Palhares, 2013 begins at the average weight of weaned calves (170 kg).

exchanges.description: Mineral supplement is used to raise the cattle. The need of mineral supplement depend on animal weight, function and season and varies from 10 g (calves and heifers right after decalving) to 80 g (bulls in the system for reproduction only) per day. Each herd stays on the system from 8 months  (heifers sold right right after decalving) up to 5 years (bulls and cows for reproduction). This is a weghted average considering the live weight of each animal, the amount per live-weight perscribed to each animal for each season, and the time the animal stays on system for each season.

flow.name: mineral supplement, for beef cattle
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/10:Manufacture of food products/108:Manufacture of prepared animal feeds/1080:Manufacture of prepared animal feeds
